results.title: Community health and you
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Health and Safety for You”
Talks about health in reference to our daily lives, eg water, and how we have to be careful and make sure water that reaches the community is clean and safe to consume. Also goes into general cleanliness in relation to sewerage and garbage to prevent disease entering our lives.

results.title: Something happened
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Healers quacks or mystics”.
Can supernatural forces be summoned at will to assist with human healing? In this episode Nevill Drury introduces us to spiritual healer, Rita McReady; the Assembly of God congregation in Mt. Gravatt, Qld, which conducts miracle services for sufferers each Sunday afternoon; the programs and philosophies practised at the Adventist Sanatorium Hospital in Sydney to mobilise the faith of patients to aid the healing process; the controversial Australian psychic surgeon, Chris Coles and finally the anointing and laying on of hands practised in a Sydney Anglican Church.

group.title: Healers quacks or mystics
group.creator_credit: Richard Corfield, Brian Nicholls, Bernice Daly and ABC

group_siblings.title: Mind the healer, mind the slayer

results.title: The New healers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Healers quacks or mystics”.
Over a quarter of a million Australians now use the services of alternative healers, a sign, perhaps, of a new understanding of the holistic nature of health care where the patient can do much to achieve good health. In this episode, presenter Nevill Drury interviews a chiropractor; naturopath, Dorothy Hall, who explains iridology and how it can be used to diagnose illness; Melbourne surgeon, Avri Sali, who explains how dietary change can prevent gallstones and bowel disease; and participants at Hopewood Health Centre and Euroa House who use relaxation techniques, healthy diet and rebirthing to improve their lives.

group_siblings.title: Mind the healer, mind the slayer

results.title: The Bodyworkers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Healers quacks or mystics”.
Bodyworkers use a range of techniques to release tension and anxiety in the body in order to release energy for life and healing. Bodyworkers believe the body holds secrets for our health and that our society’s over-emphasis on the mind, destroys the important mind/body balance. Techniques demonstrated include massage, the Alexander technique for improving posture, Rolfing (developed by US biologist, Dr. Ida Rolf) and Wilhelm Reich’s theories of sexual energy and release.

results.title: The Hidden potential
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Healers quacks or mystics”.
Marion Fine used no drugs to relieve pain after major surgery, relying instead on techniques of self-hypnosis to both relieve the pain and promote rapid healing. Marion’s case vividly demonstrates the importance of patient attitude in the healing process, a factor increasingly recognised by practitioners of traditional medicine. This program demonstrates the history and techniques of hypnosis to relieve pain, bio-feedback and the Pain Education Program for non-drug pain relief, conducted at Macquarie University in Sydney.

group_siblings.title: Mind the healer, mind the slayer

results.title: Mind the healer, mind the slayer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Healers quacks or mystics”.
At 24, vet and athlete, Ian Gawler was diagnosed with terminal bone cancer. After having one leg amputated, he was faced with only a few weeks to live. Determined to conquer his cancer, Ian embarked on a quest for an alternative cure for his illness. Now, many years later, his cancer arrested, he and his wife conduct meditation support groups for other cancer sufferers. This program follows Ian’s search and introduces us to the Melbourne pioneer of non-drug pain relief, Dr. Ainslie Meares, faith healing in the Philippines and Indian healing philosophies.

results.title: Chi: the breath of life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Healers quacks or mystics”.
In this episode, Nevill Drury visits the Oki East-West Centre to investigate disciplines which draw on eastern thought and philosophy for new directions in health care. “Chi” is the Chinese word for breath of life, an inner energy. The Chinese believe it is the source of remarkable power, so the ability to control this energy is vital for a healthy and happy life. In a healthy person, the “Chi” flows smoothly, integrating body, mind and spirit, but in an unwell person there are blockages, or imbalances. The techniques demonstrated include Oki Yoga, Tai Chi, Shiatsu (with Bruce Gyngell as the patient), macrobiotics and acupuncture.

results.title: Healers quacks or mystics
results.creator_credit: Richard Corfield, Brian Nicholls, Bernice Daly and ABC
results.brief_description: Alternative medicine offers us many options. Some approaches focus more on healthy body, others on healthy mind. But in all there is a common underlying theme, and that is that the individual can do a lot to keep themselves well. We don’t have to prop ourselves up with pills, or overload our bodies with junk food and stress. In this series, Nevill Drury takes us through a wide range of alternative therapies and treatments now available in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Corfield, Brian Nicholls, Bernice Daly and ABC

group_works.title: Mind the healer, mind the slayer

results.title: Headliner: NoviNews
results.brief_description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society.

constellations_primary.name: Fake news: too little too late
constellations_primary.description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society, something that is fast becoming one of the biggest concerns of our age.

results.description:
Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society. Players take the role of a ‘headliner’, which is like a chief editor at a news outlet. The player must decide what stories and angles to publish, and their choices have wide-reaching effects in the game world. Reject stories about creating national healthcare services? People get sick in the street. Approve stories on the benefits of synthetic recreational drugs? Addiction runs rampant.

These stories aren’t presented as obviously ‘right’ or ‘wrong’ choices: the game lets the player’s own ethics and morals guide their decisions – which can create a peaceful society or burn it to the ground.
description_for_label:

These stories aren’t presented as obviously ‘right’ or ‘wrong’ choices: the game lets the player’s own ethics and morals guide their decisions – which can create a peaceful society or burn it to the ground.
